comment._content:
It's a little more complex, and the whole postcard revolves around symbolism :
The young girl is dressed in traditional attire from 'Alsace' which is now a french department.
For centuries, Alsace was part of the great-duchy of Lorraine, and was a german-speaking area (well, not really a german-speaking, but a sub-branche of german language), but attached to the Realm of France.
In the 1870 French-German war, Alsace and Lorraine where attached to the German Reich (Germany had won this war). But many people in the region were still attached to France (there was a little something related to republic, or revolution, or democracy... why would people woud like that ??? ;) ), and the rest of french people resented the german for this 'annexion'.
Essentially, the main french motive for the WW I was to gain back Alsace & Lorraine.

This postcard shows a young alsacian girl, comforted by a french soldier, telling her : "Forget prussian (=german) rulers/oppression, it's so good to live in your home place (=France)"
At their feet, one can see the german border sign of the time, signifiying re-unification. As the general opinion in France was that Germany stole Alsace and Lorraine, this postcard was a good motivator/propaganda for french people...
